citation.article-title: Anaerobic degradation of phenol and phenol derivates by Desulfobacterium phenolicum sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Desulfobacterium phenolicum sp. nov.
Desulfobacterium phenolicum (Phe. no' li. cum. M.L. adj. phenolicum pertaining to phenol. Desulfobacterium phenolicum a sulfate-reducing bacterium oxidizing phenol.)
Curved rods of varying sizes, 1 - 1.5 μm wide and 2-3 μm long if grown with phenol.
Aromatic compounds degraded are phenol, p-cresol, 4-hydroxybenzoate, 2-hydroxybenzoate, 4-hydroxyphenylacetate, benzoate, phenylacetate, 2-aminobenzoate, indole, and phenylalanine.
Aliphatic compounds utilized are formate, acetate, butyrate, ethanol, propanol, butanol, pyruvate, malate, fumarate, maleinate, succinate, glutarate, cyclohexane-carboxylate.
Fastest growth occurs on benzoate or glutarate.
20 g NaCl and 3 g MgCl2 ⋄ 6 H2O per 1 are required for growth. 100 μmol dithionite/l are necessary to provide reducing conditions for growth.
DNA base ratio: 40.6 mol% G + C (thermal denaturation).
D. phenolieum has been enriched and isolated so far only from marine sediments.
Type strain: Ph01, DSM number 3384, deposited in the Deutsche Sammlung von Mikroorganismen.
